33.text:
Scotland is undoubtedly the home some of the
finest Deer stalking in the world. It's forested

38.text:
landscapes and picturesque mountains have
attracted deer stalkers for centuries. Thousands

43.text:
of sporting visitors come each year to take
part in this most traditional and spectacular

48.text:
of sports, pumping millions of pounds into
the country's economy. In some parts of Scotland,

53.text:
there are extensive commercial forestry plantations
and the deer use these as cover and shelter

58.text:
from the harsh mountain weather -- the stalking
technique used in woodland stalking is completely

63.text:
different to hill stalking and often utilises
high seats and dawn and dusk stalking to produce

68.text:
successful shooting. Sika deer, a non-native
species to the UK, have over the years escaped

69.text:
from captivity, and we now have large numbers
in some areas. In many cases, they have interbred

70.text:
with the local Red deer, and they are shot
and stalked in the same way. Steep banks,

71.text:
rocky dirt tracks and almost inaccessible
areas lie in wait for any stalker that wishes

75.text:
to hunt these remote areas... The perfect
companion to any hunter braving the Scottish

79.text:
terrain is the Isuzu Huntsman (with its all
terrain tyres and sophisticated 4x4 system).

87.text:
Owen Beardsmore of Cervus Uk is an incredibly
experienced stalker and has brought along

91.text:
a group of friends, who are equally as experienced,
to help manage the population of deer in the

96.text:
Kintyre Pensinula area of the Scottish moors.
Owen knows the area incredibly well as this

101.text:
is an area he frequently manages. Red Stags
and Sika deer are in healthy population throughout

102.text:
the woodland and moor; each year Owen manages
the population by removing a small percentage

107.text:
of the deer from the land by hunting it. The
stalkers ensure that the deer they hunt are

112.text:
'taken out' only when showing signs of weakness
or ill-health. This ensures the population

117.text:
remains strong and healthy and further ensures
areas do not become over populated, which

121.text:
of course ensures the deer do not become malnourished.
The deer is then transported to game dealers

124.text:
for sale in the local area. After travelling
up some of the most the steep banks, rough

128.text:
dirt tracks and rocky terrain that the Scottish
moors has to offer, Owen and his team successfully

131.text:
reach their destination all thanks to the
very reliable Isuzu D-Max Huntsman. Rip Warren

137.text:
and super stalker Keith Watson unload their
hunting gear at different areas of the woodland,

144.text:
carefully unloading their rifles from the
super safe gun drawers in the Huntsman. We

150.text:
have arrived this morning and one of the guys
has already been here for a couple of days,

154.text:
and he has shot a sika calf, and we are going
to go try and find it cause it has ran off

159.text:
into some very thick stage cover, so we are
going to try and get the dog on it and see

162.text:
if we can find it. Owen and his team head
towards the area in which Jan shot the sika.

168.text:
It was limping badly when it crossed Jan's
path, and so it was in the best interests

172.text:
of the calf to put it out of pain as it's
mother was nowhere to be seen. Despite this

177.text:
being the area in which Jan shot the sika,
there doesn't appear to be any blood and Basher

182.text:
isn't picking up on the scent. Just when they
think they're not getting anywhere with their

185.text:
search, they spot some blood and instantly
Basher picks up on the scent. Jan's shot a

191.text:
stag calf here and we have got blood there,
stripy little bit of lung, so its going into

199.text:
this thick sprouse, so hopefully we can find
it yeah. Down here look. Here, here. Its in

208.text:
here. Done about twenty metres, it was a good.
Jan lost it completely here, he looked down

215.text:
here, and we have got good blood here, and
we have found it down here, its dropped down

219.text:
into 
a ditch. Right, well down then Jan. We have
said earlier on, we have arrived and Jan had

237.text:
lost the calf that you saw, this morning,
it was on its own, it was carrying its front

243.text:
legs, so its part of our cull, that we have
shot that, but, Jan came round, saw a good

250.text:
stripe, but couldn't find the deer anyway,
so he knew I was arriving with my dog, this

253.text:
is a trained scent hound and we have literally
followed it just round the corner were Jan

258.text:
lost it and it had fallen into this ditch,
we you just couldnt see it at all. The 
boys load the sika into the Huntsman, pleased

275.text:
with the days success so far, they travel
back to the base. It will take more than this

285.text:
to satisfy Owen for today though. and so he
heads back out to take his place in a high

306.text:
seat with outstanding views across the valley.
So we are on the Kintyre peninsula and this

312.text:
is s block of woodland I have been managing
for seventeen years. It is predominantly sictcus

318.text:
sprouse, and when I took it on, it was all
a plantation, well you will see from the trees

326.text:
that are around us now that its perfect habitat
for Sika deer. We are here at the moment because

332.text:
it is just at rut time for the sika stags,
hopefully this little glade that we are overlooking

337.text:
we are going to try a little bit of calling,
see if we can coax a stag out. Owen calls,

348.text:
but the Sika aren't responding. It's incredibly
quiet and still out there and the night draws

358.text:
in bringing with it poor visibility. It's
time for Owen to head back to base, a little

365.text:
disappointed with the lack of success, but
tomorrow is another day...Refreshed and ready

377.text:
for another day ahead, Owen heads out into
the day. The morning brings with it a beautiful

382.text:
red glow, bringing all the autumnal colours
of the woodland alive. Hoping the Sika may

387.text:
have moved from area to another, Owen makes
his way slowly and carefully along the treeline.

393.text:
Can you see the bark stripping there look.
Sika deer are nutritious for the damage they

401.text:
do in the forest, and you can see there, fresh
bark stripping where they have been feeding.

407.text:
It has just turned first light, and I have
been stalking for probably half an hour, and

412.text:
we are getting to an area where it is particularly
busy for sika, so we are going to make our

424.text:
way down one of these rides, there has been
quite a bit of traffic along this ride, so

432.text:
there will be plenty of dung, then we are
gonna cut round, and it drops into a big open

436.text:
space, which is very popular with them. We
havent heard any stag calling yet, but we

438.text:
are gonna sit ourselves down and try and do
a bit of calling. Silently and carefully,

444.text:
Owen moved down towards the open basin. With
the hope of spotting a deer in the open, he

449.text:
settles on a hillside where he has great visibility.
He glasses the vast space and tree lines surrounding

455.text:
it, but still there's no sign of life. Even
a few calls don't appear to rouse a response.

476.text:
We have just stalked up the edge of this sinus
sprouse plantation and we have come over this

487.text:
wallow, and if you have a look we have got
some fresh dung here from last night, this

492.text:
is were a sika stag has been, and he has been
wallowing in hereand you can see where he

499.text:
has been scrapping the ground with his antlers,
and thrashing about over there and rolling.

507.text:
Sika and Red deer love to do this, and particularly
during the rut, to mark there territories

515.text:
and get themselves as strong smelling as they
can. Just found a pouch from where a hound

520.text:
or a stag has been sleeping for the night
and it is really fresh, either a hind or a

526.text:
stag has been lying down and its really fresh,
just have a look how it has curled itself

532.text:
round like a dog to make a nice bed for the
night and settle down. Despite the clear signs

537.text:
of deer having beeded up for the night, the
only sign of life are the birds. Cox is the

544.text:
one with the black back and the rosy red chest,
the duller one is the female nearest to it,

558.text:
not many of them about nowadays, especially
up here. Disappointed, Owen calls it a day

574.text:
and heads back to base through the astounding
scenery of Kintyre in the Huntsman. Once the

586.text:
Huntsman is back at base, Owen and Jan load
up the truck with the deer taken that day

591.text:
by Jan and prepare it for the game dealers.
2 red staffs and a sika fit into the rear

600.text:
of the truck with ease. Thankfully, the Huntsman
boasts a rubber non-slip floor mat in the

604.text:
rear, which makes the transportation of Owen
and Jan's carcasses much more straight forward.

609.text:
It'll be really straight forward for them
to remove the blood that the carcasses have

616.text:
left behind too. Not content with the weekend's
action, Owen decides he will take one last

623.text:
opportunity at shooting a deer. But the weather
takes a turn for the worse... The rain becomes

633.text:
so bad, there's no way they can carry on.
With the rain pounding down hard, and the

639.text:
puddles getting increasingly deeper it's crucial
Owen and the guys retrieve the Quad from the

643.text:
forest. It's not as easy as it sounds, with
the weather really working against them in

648.text:
the quest to tow out the trailer. Luckily,
they get to put the Huntsman to the test which

653.text:
makes light of this hard work and ensures
everyone and everything returns to base safe

658.text:
and sound. Ok we have been up in Scotland
all week and we have had the dirtiest of all

665.text:
weather, we have had the Isuzu D-Max Huntsman
on trial, it has been more than capable, we

673.text:
have had the quad trailer on the back and
it has performed absolutely marvellously,

677.text:
been very impressed. I use a different type
of 4x4, but I defiantly will be considering

681.text:
this one for my next one, especially how its
been laid out with the kit, and all the boxes

685.text:
and everything, we have had all our rifles
in there, we have had 4 red stags here which

688.text:
we have took to the game larder, its been
really good. The team head home after loading

693.text:
up the truck; the one thing this trip has
shown us is that despite being overwhelmingly

698.text:
experienced it's still an enormous challenge
taking out deer and managing the population
